stem: A tall, thin 19-year-old male reports sudden left-sided chest pain while playing basketball. Examination shows absent breath sounds on the left. RR 28, SpO2 91%. Complete the bowtie to guide management.

rationale.correct: Young, tall, thin males are at risk for spontaneous pneumothorax due to bleb rupture. Sudden chest pain + absent sounds = air in pleural space. Priority is re-expansion (Chest tube) and oxygenation. Tracheal deviation is a critical sign of progression to tension pneumothorax.
rationale.incorrect: Incentive spirometry is for post-op atelectasis prevention, not for re-expanding a collapsed lung. Morphine is for pain but second to physiological stability.
clinicalPearls: SpO2 and Tracheal position are the 'watchdog' parameters here.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: A simple pneumothorax becomes a tension pneumothorax ONLY when the pressure builds enough to shift the trachea and collapse the heart (Shock).

mnemonic.title: SP
mnemonic.expansion:
S = Spontaneous
P = Pneumothorax

Key Actions: Apply 100% Oxygen via Non-rebreather mask; Prepare for Chest Tube insertion (Thoracostomy)
Key Monitoring: Respiratory rate and effort; Position of the trachea (Deviation)

Priority is re-expansion (Chest tube) and oxygenation. Tracheal deviation is a critical sign of progression to tension pneumothorax. SpO2 and Tracheal position are the 'watchdog' parameters here.

reviewUnits.body: A simple pneumothorax becomes a tension pneumothorax ONLY when the pressure builds enough to shift the trachea and collapse the heart (Shock).

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Spontaneous Pneumothorax
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Apply 100% Oxygen via Non-rebreather mask; Prepare for Chest Tube insertion (Thoracostomy). Monitor: Respiratory rate and effort; Position of the trachea (Deviation). Incentive spirometry is for post-op atelectasis prevention, not for re-expanding a collapsed lung. Morphine is for pain but second to physiological stability.
